text: At the first stage of the class ,he would introduce some basics stuff about photography and how to use different functions about camera. Then we will practice during the class outside the classroom.  After we handed in our homework (5 photos we took during field trips), we had to share to everyone. Though it is not serious presentation that we just had to speak on our seats, it made the class boring! Moreover, the instructor allowed people to speak in Cantonese. Therefore you won't understand what they are talking about.He is a nice photographer who would answer your questions patiently. Though sometimes he would speak in Cantonese to make locals understand easily, you can just raise your and say you don't understand. He would explain in English for you.The class takes shape much like a generic drama class, with a focus on practically trying out stuff. As it is just a 1 credit course, it just briefly touches upon a lot of ideas about drama an stage movement but doesn't explore them in any depth.

Attendance is pretty much mandatory and ties directly to your grade.Excellent. She has a very hands on approach to teaching the class, and really promotes interaction between classmates. With the casual atmosphere maintained in class, it feels like you are just hanging out with friends rather than taking a course.A few notes in the LMES that helped give a structure to the practical http://learning.To quote, "the stories should follow a clearly defined structure from (inception and cause) to the (climax and underlying message)"

Every class covered a new theme and was more hands-on and interactive than theoretical. It focused on creativity, body language, facial expressions and on-the-feet thinking.Was a wonderful experience. She was expressive and elaborate in explanations. Two extra lessons were organised for further practice. Everyone was given personal attention and feedback which went a long way in self improvement.The first two classes are introduction to some types of puppet, she only READ the ppt. The rest of the classes are totally useless, we just did our own paper cutting work. Don't expect to learn anything, you already know everything from your commonsense. The final showing is a shadow puppet performance with the script of Alice in Wonderland(the teacher decided the script). It was so boring.The instructor doesnt know how to manage time. Also, no useful feedbacks were given to students. We just did our own thing during every class.Basic Graphic Design principles.
Usage of points, lines, shapes, colours etc
Elements of contrast, focus, repetition & spacing.
Small introduction to typography and layout design.

Final project to implement all that you've learned into a poster design for a campaign (you'll need to present your initial idea, progress presentation, make the poster itself, submit a group project report and record all you've done in a logbook)
Also includes software workshop on Photoshop and Illustrator, not compulsory if you already know them.

There is also a lesson where a guest speaker, who is himself a graphic designer, came and shared his experience in working in the field, giving us a glimpse of how graphic design works in real life.Alice is a very nice tutor. Her tone is comfortable and at the same time encouraging to students.
She is very experienced in the field of Design Education and has been affiliated to HKPU Design School for quite some time.

Since the class is small, she is always willing to give us useful comments on our draft designs. Some may find it critical and nitpicking, but in the field of Design, taking critics is a major part of your job, so get used to it.I entered this course because I thought I would have been able to learn more computer-related design skills such as Adobe Photoshop and other design tools. Surprisingly, it was mostly about theories in graphic design and the only time we got to learn design programs (Adobe Photoshop and Illustrator) were in 3 supplementary workshops after the classes. So if you are looking for a class to learn more about design programs, this probably isn't the course for you.Alice overall is an okay instructor, but be prepared to jot down notes in this class, because her slides are picture-heavy and thus she says she cannot give it to us due to the pictures' copyrights.

Personally I feel she's a little forceful on opinions when this is supposed to be a more 'creative' class and that she might be prejudiced to those who can draw reasonably well. She does tend to miss people out during discussions and end discussions so it's probably better to be more proactive in discussions as it seems to affect class participation grades greatly.The prof is very nice and interactive.
She will do a demo in class one time for each topics and tell u the technique used in painting and coloring briefly. However u have to practice a lot to copy her technique.
When u are practicing in class she will come to guide and correct each person.  The prof also tries to help us improve the painting every time before submitting the work.

Note that the teaching and all the materials are in Chinese.  This course might not be suitable for native english speakersThe instructor is nice and punctual. And she is enthusiastic with advising students with their work which I appreciate. It seems she also teaches Chinese painting II. The course is conducted in Cantonese so it's actually difficult for non-local students...All lectures are conducted in cantonese, which is really great. Instructor spent time with students for individual advising, telling each of us what to improve.

But, sometimes she did talk boringly during demonstration making us fell alseep...The content is interesting, and very practical. This course is very different from other uni courses as there is nothing to memorise or recite. The class is similar to the art classes we had in high school.The instructor is very friendly and kind. She will be very willing to help if you are facing difficultiesThe Instructor introduces a good range of different styles of dance and questions that different boundaries of dance itself. The content is well researched, though the instructor is heavily influenced by American Works. It provides, what I feel is a good introduction to Contemporary dance.

The Practical part of the lesson was more engaging. The instructor introduced motions of different levels of difficulty. There is also a lot of emphasis on strengthening the core and thigh muscles.The instructor is passionate and loves the art form. He has good knowledge and has researched adequately about Contemporary dance. He is aware that there are non-dancers who take the course and makes sure that he introduces a wide range of motions and exercises to strengthen core.Content is interesting because they teach you about creativity, but there was no indication that the only "art" portion we'd learn about was film.I thought it'd be more interactive since it is an art class but the title is misleading because it seems to be lots of powerpoint lectures and lab book work on your own time. The lecturers are dry. They try to get the small class to participate but the same people half-heartedly volunteer.The course is about training your brain to be more creative. It is actually quite interesting and fun. Marketing student might find it quite useful.The teachers were from poluU as I remember. It could be very boring when they were showing a lot of art work in the powerpoint. However, it was quite relaxing when it comes to group activities. you might have to share your thoughts to the whole class in nearly every lesson but it was very casual. The class size is very small so you can easily be friends with others normally.
p.s. quite a lot of foreigners and exchange students took this course at that timeNot as experimental as I would have liked.

Each class starts with some blind drawing and continuous line drawing to warm-up. Then the drawings you work on will be whatever idea the instructor has for you to try. The whole idea is just to let you think/draw out of the box, nothing concrete is taught.

I like experimenting in art on my own anyway so this course was slightly dull; I've seen the book the instructor was using for ideas in my local bookshop. If you've only been drawing specific things like realism or animes or just kind of unexperimental, then this course will be more challenging and different.

For our semester we did greyscale pixel drawing, motion drawing, drawing a figure using shapes etc. The instructor is quite free though, not requiring us to follow the original idea exactly (that would kind of ruin the point).Your typical art teacher. She's very free and will tell you not to force yourself to do something. Will flexibly change the content and pacing according to the class.

Best part of the teaching is that she still made me realise that there is more to explore, that I can push the boundaries more, but all that came from one-to-one talks and not the class. Did I mention the class was a bit dull for me?
So yeah, typical art teacher.mainly about the basic technique of Chinese painting
the background and history of the Chinese painting somehow is also included
the skills taught have color mix, how to draw and paint different flowers, how to draw a cockquite polite and friendly
patient enough to provide adequate advice to let us know how to improve
each time when we start a new topic, she would firstly demonstrate to show us the techniques and the things we need to pay attention
overall is satisfactoryClass was quite small and the instructor was nice. I really enjoyed the course.

Class was very relaxed without strict regulations. My class was at 9 am but most of the people came in 5~10mins late. There was one major artwork exhibition, and it was fun doing it.We don't actually get to learn anything (skills), but we got to try a new way of drawing such as drawing without looking, drawing with one single line ...etc and it was very interesting.the course covered around 160 years of fashion industry in 1 month, and it was expected that it was not going to be something in great detail, however, personally speaking, I think it is good enough for non-fashion background students to study the characteristic of each era and famous designers. Also, the course provided chances to practice sewing techniques .The lecture were mainly divided in to 2 parts, 40-45 mins theory session, and remaining 1.5 hours is for practical skill learning of how to sew. There was a TA and she gave me good and practical advice on techniques.Lectures are on Fashion History. Reading the textbook, which is available at the library provides just a little more detail than delivered in class. The lectures are not difficult or boring at all. There are only few points to remember for each era, such as silhouette, fabric choice, patterns, which comes easy if you're interested in vintage fashion and the current trend. However, I did came in the course expecting a bit more tailoring skills to be taught. We were taught to make simple projects like a skirt or a dress, but we were only taught techniques and not how to design and produce from scratch. I was quite disappointed there wasn't more time for learning how to draw a pattern, properties of different fabrics, or color theory.Silvio is a fun teacher and did a great job delivering his passion for fashion and experience in the industry. A seamstress was responsible for the practical exercises. She was experienced and patient.The course has two parts: dancing part and theory part

Tutor will base on your ability to arrange an array of routines, including the classical  Chinese dance and folk dance. As most of my classmates have learnt Chinese dance before, the difficulty and standard would then become higher which may become hard to some beginners.

For theory part, students only need to jot down the notes and reflection in each lesson and submit a journal at the end of the course.Tutor is patient to teach each students and would give some advices. She aims to let students enjoy to experience the Chinese dance and thus focuses more on this part. She would briefly talk about the theory part at the end of each lesson in a relax way.One of the best course and surely the most interesting course I have taken in HKUST. Very different from any other course. Cover different singing techniques and body gestures, staging and performance. But the accapella part is removed due to limit of time. In the second half, requires much time to watch others' performance instead of individual teaching.The instructor can tackle each person's weak point and provide guidance on how to improve them. Very useful if you really want to improve singing in this course. Patrick is nice and makes you feel confident when performing.Teacher name: patrick. Good. The lesson atmosphere is good ad relaxing as the classmates are quite fun, a lot of jokes.Covered most of the European historic events from the 14th century to Europe today. Most of the contents are given in ppt slides, little notes needed to be jotted in lectures.
One summary sheet with key terms is provided in each lecture for easier understanding.

But you still need a good level of English to cope with a large number of terms.Prof. is good. He is passionate in this subject. He explains the content well. So, attending lectures definitely helps your understanding. The only shortcoming is that you need time to familiarize with his accent. (He is an Italian with a Hong Kongese wife) Though, his speaking pace is quite slow (also a bit boring sometimes), you can follow the content most of the time.The content was very interesting, take the time to think about the areas he delves into and look and research into what it is like today.Excellent and interactive teaching, and Prof Wu didn't care your pronunciation of PTH. He was patient and kind to all of his students.The grading was straightforward, if you pay attention to his lectures it will be clear how to formulate your arguments to find success in this class.Not much workload, 1 mid term and 1 final essay, 1 project,1 small essay. Final essay's title choose your own title for your essay.Lectures cover different topics of Chinese and Western cultures and values.

Contents are quite interesting and are useful for the essay. Many reading materials but not necessary to read it.Dr. Nam is nice and likes joking. He has arranged some optional lectures for students who want to know more and counsel for their essay. However I skipped many lessons and no more comment on teaching.The content is interesting. Many PRS but not count in grading. Teachers are very very very nice!!!Teachers are very very very nice! Dr. Nam will offer some optional cantonese and putonghua tutorials for students who do not understand the content in lesson. Though the essay topics are quite difficult, Dr. Nam is so generous that he is always willing to give us directions and ideas.Lecture contents cover different topics and not badly design - from morality to destiny. Contents are interesting for people who love to think about these abstract stuffs. But sometimes topics are quite mixed together and hard to follow.Very bad english... Very hard to understand even when I am from Hong Kong too... I feel sorry for the internationals in the lecture hall cause I don't think they even get half of what the professor says in lecture... Professor always tries to be funny but failed... But he teaches very well out of lecture when he held extra tutorial sessions.Just follow the instruction of the course.
Learning concepts about the Chinese and Western philosophy.
Not hard for local/mainland student to understand.Prof. Nam is a really good professor.
As a local student, it is easy to understand his jokes and slangs.
He is really responsible. He even arranged optional review classes in both Cantonese and Mandarin.

Basically, attend these optional classes, you may catch up the content in the lectures.Lectures cover wide range of Chinese and Western culture and values including Utilitarianism, Kantianism, Mohism, Confucianism, Daoism, destiny and well-beings. Majority of the topics will be tested on quizzes and only one concept out of Utilitarianism, Kantianism, Mohism, Confucianism is required to appear in your essay and you can find some useful points on Dr Nam's recommended readings.Dr Nam managed to deliver his powerpoint slides with some real-life examples which helps me understand some difficult terms and theories. However, his English has a large room for improvement which you need extra attention on his class since some questions in the quiz will be disclosed on lectures. Dr Susanna Ho and Dr Nam both spent extra time for consultation on the 1000-word essay, which one should realize what they ask for and how one can improve from the draft essay. The teaching on lectures was a bit not understandable but both quizzes only test your memory of the exact wordings in the ppt. However, the teaching on the tutorial is essential for you to write the essay smoothly and attendance and some little practices on Canvas are required.This course is an introductory course for music composition, covers music from the Baroque period to the early 20th centry. You will learn different types of scales, technique to write polyphonic music, and the very important counterpoint.

This course is well structured. The progress of the course and the content of each lesson is clearly stated on a handout which will be given at the start of the semester.Professor Kaila is one of the best professors i have met in ust. He has showed great enthusiasm in teaching throughout the course. He will answer your questions seriously and help you in every possible way. He can also remember everyone's name in the class.

During the lesson, he will always interact with you to ensure you understand what he just taught.basic music theory (less than Grade 8 level), including scales, chords, intervals, etc. Don't expect too much to learn if you have music background. On the contrary, you can learn a lot in a short period of time if you don't have any music background.The instructor is excellent in music but he is strict. You can hardly chat or make a noise in lessons, perhaps he is too sensitive to sound.

Tutorials are NOT helpful at all but attendance are required.The instructor teaches at a good pace that he gave some examples throughout his teaching. One lecture generally teaches one topic/ one complex subtopic.

In tutorials, it is good that the TA sometimes urges some students to answer in order to know whether u understand. There are some harder listening exercise as the semester goes on. In the beginning, you may be required to distinguish major/ minor, duple/triple, but at the end you need to dictate a short melody played by TA (played by instructor in final exam). There are some exercises uploaded to canvas which is caring.Started with basic stuff of music theory to nearly grade 8 music theory level. Quite hard to catch up for ppl with no music background.Clear and organized. He is quite strict on attendence tho. Tutor is really nice!!Average grading, only that the mean is usually quite high (there are students who are really good....). Exam is really difficult for the listening part. You have differetiate 7th chords and do a melodic dictation.Quite heavy. Got hw every lesson, tutorial every week, concert review, composition exercise. Tutorial is quite useful but also demanding. A lot of ear training exercises.The content covered most of the ABRSM Grade 1-5  and few Grade 6-8 music theory.

Mainly about pitches, key signatures, time signatures, scales, intervals, triads, seventh chords, modulation, cadences etc.The professor is passionate and use piano playing in assisting his teaching. He is very nice and willing to answer your questions after the lectures. He may use students' composition works to tell us what is good or bad.

The tutorials are conducted by his TA, mainly focus on aural training (melodic dictation, rhythm dictation, distinguish the triads, chords and cadences) and point us the common mistakes in your homework. The training will help you to familiarize the exam aural part.Easy stuff, all about simple theories in ABRSM syllabus. You need to buy a book (either e-book or printed) for assignment. For course details, see attachment.Prof. Kaila:
I think Kaila is an excellent and experienced professor, with (comparatively) clearer English speaking, I can almost understand what he meant in lectures.
Some flaws. Kaila won't write down some key terms that are needed to understand.
He is very kind that likely to answer your question.
Galison Lau:
In the tutorials, he explained many mistakes that found in our assignments, and try to illustrate to us what is the correct one.
The main part of the tutorial is ear training. I think he did not show us the skills, only doing some exercises...
He is also likely to answer your question.Basic music theory, focusing on reading, writing and analytical listening.
Main focus:
Writing skills: major and minor keys, intervals, chords, chord progressions and simple harmonic analysis
Aural skills:
recognizing chords and intervals, notating simple melodies and rhythms by ear, distinguishing major and minor, meters and textures
The first half of the course (before midterm) is easier for those who have music theory grade 5.Average.
Using the textbook to assist your revision after lectures will be helpful in case you can't catch up with what the lecturer says.

Tutorials are not too helpful though its aim is to train and consolidate your aural skills because not many practical and useful techniques are taught.People say that this course is dominated by people who have music background. I also have taken music theory exam level 5 in the past. I have knowledge of everything taught in the first half of the course. But the second half exceeds music theory exam level 5 and can become a bit difficult sometimes. Homework and exam are quite easy so losing 1 or 2 marks can really downgrade your course grade. But overall, for me, I feel the course curriculum is well designed for people who want to learn music and is very useful. You get to learn from scratch, learn music composition, and build up pretty good foundation.The lecturer is solemn for most of the times and do not allow people chat during the lecture. He will pick you to answer question if you do not pay attention. Also, attendance is taken for every lesson and tutorial. The tutor can remember everybody's face. It sounds pretty horrible but I found it not really harsh if you want to learn seriously.You know all content before midterm if you know grade 5 music theory. Content after midterm is a little bit difficult. They require you to be able to know the chord when the instructor plays it, and do melody dictation, though not difficult in fact.Nothing special. Not very interesting but not boring. Quite easy to understand if you have attended the lesson.Content is very simple. If you practice enough you can get good grade easily.

Four lunch talks and two concerts are compulsory, but well... they are pretty lame, few good compositions.To be honest, I don't find the teaching helpful. But Prof is a fun guy. Use teoria, cuz music theory is about practicing :) There's raffling in class, so.. if you wish to use iprs set to take attendance, find someone to answer questions for you or you'll have one absence.The content covers from some basic concept such as note, rhythm, interval, scales, chords. And finally, help you to do some analysis on the composition then compose a short piece of a final project. All these seem easy to handle if you have a strong foundation of music theory.
Some contents are more than so-called "music theory" but it is really cool to get access to basic composition skills and sight-singing.

Tutorial will concentrate on listening practice since there's a 30 point listening test in the final exam.He's a graceful Finnish guy. I really like his improvised piano piece during the lecture. But it may be somewhat boring for those have a musical background.It is about basic western classical music theories, a bit harder than ABRSM Level 5 Theory Exam as identifying four sevenths cadences are required at final exam which is really difficult. Not recommend for those haven't taken any theory exams before if you hope for a good grade.The lecturer and tutor both teach well and they really can help you learn more and use the skills learnt in lectures and tutorials.
Lecture is mostly about theories and tutorial is mostly about composition skills and identifying melodies and cadences.HUMA 2104 is an introduction to the basics of music theory, with an emphasis on
reading, writing, and analytical listening. Writing skills taught in the course include pitch
notation using treble and bass clefs, rhythmic notation, the construction of scales in major
and minor keys, intervals, chords, chord progressions, and simple harmonic analysis.
Aural skills taught in the class and practiced in tutorials include recognizing chords and
intervals, notating simple melodies and rhythms by ear, and distinguishing between
tonalities (major and minor), meters (duple and triple), and textures (homophonic and
polyphonic). The course culminates in a final project of composing a simple tonal piece.Instructor is interesting, for both lectures and tutorials.
Can't be late for class. Attendance is taken through PRS at the beginning of class sharply.

It is required to buy a textbook cause homework are attached at the back of the book. The book cost ~HKD$400. Be prepare for this when taking this course,The content is said to be intended for non-music background but obviously 99% have good music theory background. Student needed to buy a textbook which is either online with restricted time or buy a hard copy. Learning from note, pitch, scale, chords, inversions and cadences. Students with music background should feel very easy but non-music background students should feel depressed. A progress learning of how to compose a short melody will be taught.The textbook is good to read and easy to understand for even a new learner. But the instructor is too boring. Even all the lessons are compulsory but the lesson is not worthy to take. Do think twice if you wanna use a course and attendance to learn this.- Lecture materials are quite boring if you have any music theory background
- Prof. tries to make jokes but...
- Major/minor, chords, Rhythm, Listening...
- Chord listening and melody dictation part may be hard even if you have music background.- Needa buy an expensive textbook (pdf format) and the license only last for one semester.
- Tutorials and Lectures (Both cant skip)
- Requires self-learning
- You must follow the 'rules' of the professor
- PRS once the lecture begins, never delayBasic music theory
The content will be easy if you have some knowledge in music.

Even if you don't, the textbook is well-written and very easy to understand. The final exam and midterm are almost the same as the assignments in the textbook, which are easy after reading the textbook.Classes are boring in my opinion.

The professor is very strict about attendances and participation. He only gives you 1 minute and 30 seconds for PRS from the time that class starts and after that you're counted as late. Although he dislikes students not focusing on class, he only mentions it and doesn't record it to grade students based on such attitude.

In tutorials the instructor asks some questions and students need to listen and sing as a group to review the contents. Tutorials are basically review of the lectures, but attendance is crucial.The content is interesting for those who studied a bit of music before and wants to know more about how to compose a song. It is less useful in the first half of semester but easy to understand. It gets more useful but difficult in the second half of semester.Teaching in CYT, the instructor is nice but the way he taught is not really suitable for people with no music background. i.e. He usually demonstrates the rhythme and other tones on the piano and picks people to answer random questions. Even though the content before mid-term is easy, the melodies and content became harder to understand and hear after the mid-term.The content was all about basic Grade 5 music theory which I have learnt before, so the content was easy to me.The teaching was fun as the professor demonstrated examples by playing the piano and playing recordings to us quite often. The lessons were relaxing.I have attended all lectures and only skipped one tutorial. Most of my assignments are above average. My mid-term was 102/104. I got an A for this course at the end. It was quite easy to get an A if you are a music enthusiasts.The workload was quite heavy. There were one assignment each week. You also have to attend a compulsory concert, write a concert report and do a composition at the end of the semester.All the basic theories from music notation, scales, intervals, chords to harmonies are covered throughout this course.
Attendance is required for every lecture and tutorial class.

This course is an advantage for those who have prior music theory knowledge and background. But it is challenging if you have no any music knowledge at all.Teaching is good, in a sense that Kaila will explain the concepts in a very detailed and clear way and make sure you understand them. He sometimes will make fun/jokes in class so as to grab your attention.
I don't have a hard time catching up with the class because I have studied some basic music theory before. But it is still fine for everyone if you review the concepts after the class.
Also you will have to pay close attention to the instructor because he speaks quite fast.

Kaila is passionate talking and teaching students off the class. Overall his teaching is good.The content is all about basic music theory , such as key signature , chords and so on . So , the course is suitable for those who have already study music theory.

attendance : every lecture and tutorial lessonsThe teaching of the instructor is quite interesting and clear . But for those people who have not studied any music theory beforehand , it would be relatively hard for them to understand what instructor taking about in the lesson . But if we are willing to spend more time to do revision at home , it would be fine .Content covers Theory exams Trinity grades 1 and 2. Basic music notation, Scales, Intervals, Rhythm, Mater, Harmony, Chords. Its not very hard for someone who has some prior knowledge. Course can be challenging if you have no idea about these terms whatsoever.Teaching is pretty good. Very thorough will the material and super knowledgeable. Attendance is graded and has a fair weightage to the course grade so missing lectures and tutorials will affect your grade for sure.A lot of my friends missed lectures every now and then, as did I. (Hint, for our sem, he usually takes attendance twice in a row, then goes easy on us for a while) And even when I went, I never really gave the course my attention (apologies again). The professor basically drones on in the background while students sit and type at their computers. But Zhang min still enthusiastically carries on without a care in the world, and he really seems to be quite passionate about the material. However, if you're more accustomed to skipping classes and cramming before tests, at least have a friend to fill in your attendance for you (which itself requires a certain level of skill, since the TA counts how many students are sitting in a row, and hands out attendance slips accordingly...but she could always make a mistake, you never know;) and read the required reading. At least the first quarter of it. That will basically serve as your surrogate tutor.The course content are quite interesting.
It give you some different aspect to look at language.
To remind you, this course is definitely not about literature but the analysis of language. It never matter if you are not good at literature at all.
Some tips for you:

Understanding the concept of conceptual metaphor and metonymy are very important for all of your analysis throughout this course.  Try to work on (or just take a look with) those provided exercises to strengthen your understanding!Professor will explain all lecture materials in a very very detailed way! (but actually, as the lecture materials are quite easy to understand, you can read them by your own. so I seldom pay attention during lectures:p)This course is mainly focus on analysis of language, but not about literature. So if you are not good at literature, this is not a problem.
Content : Metaphor, metonymy
The content is quite interesting, talk about the metaphor  in daily life.Professor is full of passion, yet sometimes it is quite boring.
I always read the notes by myself.It is about chinese and english metaphor.
i think the content is not much, repeat the similar topic.
The content is very simple, what u need to do is just reading all the examples and do all the exercises.The prof is very cute, he teaches with lots of body language and trys to make some gag.

He gives lots of example and exercises to illustrate one statement, but due to too many examples, sometimes I get bored and play with my phone.The course encompasses a wide range of diverse topics such as literary metaphors, metaphors in everyday language, and metonymy.The teacher is good and well-prepared. I tried to listen carefully for the first few classes and I found it really interesting. He uses a lot of examples and graphs to make it more vivid. The one that impresses me most is LOVE IS A CONTAINER. However, if you are really not interested in this topic, the class will be more than boring to you. I saw many students fall asleep in class actually.¡ú_¡úMetaphors and metonymy! Analyze all kinds of metaphors. It sounds that every class it's about the same things and  theories so I felt bored. Dig into many commonly used phrases and sentences like "falling in love" and show that in this sentence, there's a metaphor which is LOVE IS A CONTAINER, to show that metaphors are commonly used as a conceptual tool to help people understand things.Vivid, always use actions or graphs to explain metaphors. Really excited every class and always laughing at his own jokes regardless of all the asleep students....The content is interesting. It may change your view towards the language you use everyday because after understanding the concepts you will discover that nearly every sentences we speak contains metaphors.

It does not need good language skill, but having good English has a little bit advantage.The teaching is fine. But I dont really listen to the class because I was there only for attendance. I think I only attended less than half of the class.

There are a lot of so-called required readings, though I only read one. These readings may not really help with your exams and your grade whatsoever.As suggested in the topic, it is about conceptual metaphors in both Chinese and English. Metonymy was also covered.
It is better for Chinese to take the course as many examples and exam questions were in Chinese. Most foreigners dropped the course after the first lesson.

Do not expect it to be a language course. It is more like understanding the logic in the metaphors. So fluency in English or Chinese wouldn't help that much as long as you can read.The teaching pace is quite slow and the tone of the professor was really boring so I didn't pay much attention in class. I just went to class for attendance taking. But the professor taught the materials in great detail(according to my minimal attention paid), so it would help on some topics that are difficult to grasp.
The power point slides basically got everything needed. I just read through the slides before quiz and exam.This is the pre-reg course for GCS Year 1 student.
This course is about the general history of China between the 1830s to 1940s, in terms of the social, political, economic and cultural perspective.
Week 1: Intro+China before Opium War
Week 2-3: opium war
Week 4-6: foreign invasion of China
Week 6-7: Reforms
Week: 7-8: Revolution, Republic and warlords
Week: 9-10: Rise of nationalism
Week 11-12: Fascist KMT versus righteous CCP
Week 13: Second Sino-Jap War

The topic is for reference only as the schedule always lag behind and may not have time cover all the topics.For the lecture, there is no ppt provided but only lecture outline is given. You need to jot down what he is saying quickly as the content he has spoken is similar to the final exam question. The format of final exam is long essay questions.

There are four tutorial sessions and one question (similar to essay question) and the coverage of assigned reading will be provided to you in advance to think of. Each one  need to speak sth and discuss the question given. Every student will be appointed as a leader of discussion in at least one session of tutorial.This course is about modern Chinese history (1800s-1949).

discussion is encouragedThis course concentrates on the themes of love and death in literature and on ways and the cultural milieu in which writers have handled these themes. It is the aim of this course to guide students to approach literature as a form of entertainment and enlightenment. We will study not only canonical works of ¡°high¡± literature but those of popular literature as well. For students who wish to learn the interpretive strategies and understand the thematic significance of literary texts, this course provides guidance to both aesthetic appreciation and recognition of psychological and philosophical issues raised in literature. Readings are primarily poems and short stories. We will also watch some films and discuss the relation of film and literature in terms of these themes. Topics include the construction of subjectivity, gender and sexuality, self and society, and the meaning of existence in the modern world.
Half of the readings are in Chinese. Students are expected to have a reading ability of Chinese. The course will be conducted in English.
¦Ë Class attendance. Attendance is absolutely essential to this course. Absences exceeding one allowance will result in a lower grade.
¦Ë Participation. Students should prepare the required reading before each lecture and actively participate in class as well as in group discussion.
¦Ë Midterm exam. Essay questions.
¦Ë Final exam. Essay questions.Discussion

Though there will be readings, I didn't read any of them as I think most of the questions in the quiz will be based on the slides.I am personally very interested in ethics and morality so I rate the content very highly. The first part of the semester you look at three big ethical theories - Virtue Ethics, Deontology, and Utilitarianism. Then you try and apply these different ways of thinking to issues we face in society today ,such as Climate change, animal rights, and poverty. I found the content very relevant and eye-opening.I did like the professor because he never told you how to think, he always presented both sides of an argument and tried to get people to do the same. He also spent a lot of time explaining concepts which i personally enjoyed because sometimes I had no idea what the text meant. However, his powerpoints were just walls of text. They did come in handy though when you needed to revise.The content is not very hard, and gets more and more interested.
1st part: Ethical Theories. Aristotle's Virtue Ethics, Kant's Deontology.
2nd part: Ethical Theories and Contemporary issues. Mill's and Bentham's Utilitarianism. Discussion about crime and punishment, death penalty.
3rd part: Contemporary issues
Euthanasia, hunger and poverty, animal rights and environment.

I think the "contemporary issues" part is quite fun and I'm really intersted in it. It is related to our lives and it makes me think about how I should treat the animals and the environment, which are some topics that I have never thought thoroughly before!! And the theories are the basic theories of the ethics world. It is of no disadvantage knowing more of it as long as you are interested. The theories learnt in the first part will be applied in the 2nd and 3rd part. So I kinda felt like the knowledge is really "applied"haahah.The teaching is a bit boring. The professor is somehow just reading the PPT. If you read the materials, it would be much clearer because he explains the key parts.

The ppt is really ugly cause THERE ARE ONLY WORDS ON IT. And the structure is quite boring. But be careful with the ppt. This semester, there are questions like "what are the 2nd and 3rd point of XXXX"(6 points raised in class)
There are group discussions every class. The group is randomly assigned and if your group is active(like mine), you get interesting insights from your peers.

Also, she often looks at the computer or her notes while she is teaching £¨I guess that is because her spoken English is not very good, she just wants to make sure she does not speak anything wrong£©. Hence, there are many students feel bored during classes.
However, she is definitely a sincere teacher. Although she won't create any quizzes for what she has taught, she still pays lots of effort on the course content £¨e.g. using various examples£©.

Also, she does care students. Before the first tutorial, every student was asked to prepare a brief introduction of his or her cultural background. She memorized all! She often asks the cultural experience of some students base on their characteristics and background. For example, when we are talking about the life in student hall, she may "interview" students from foreign countries.  £¨This is quite nice). She is also quite acceptive. One of our students was not available to do the presentation, she allowed him to make a video. If you find it difficult to do your presentation on the designated date, you could talk to her and postpone your presentation £¨if no time clash£©. Also, the deadline for submitting the final paper is quite late £¨the last day of examination£©.
Besides, the learning atmosphere she creates is quite relaxing. For example, there's a group providing snacks to the audience during the presentation. She's chilled with that.

A total of 2 quizzes and 5 online discussion are taken into account for assessing your grading.
Attendance is optional as it is only counted as bonus point to your grading but not compulsory.

However, the most important factor contributing to your final grade is the performance of your FINAL ESSAY. The fact is that even with a high score in quizzes, a poor FINAL ESSAY really affects your grade finally.The course is divided into two parts, lecturing and writing workshops. You listen and learn different moral ethics during lectures, for example utilitarianism, kantianism, mohism and so on. You then apply what you have learnt in your final essay, which you will learn how exactly should you write it in the five writing workshops that you are required to attend. Overall it is a course that teaches you both essay writing techniques and traditional moral ethics, which is quite useful as it is an eye opener and essay writing skills are essential in university life.The teaching is acceptable, the professor who delivered the lectures had terrible English so it was quite a struggle to listen. The professor who taught me in the writing workshop was quite helpful and friendly so generally it was nice.Content is interesting. There is no need to answer any questions in class. Of course, you can skip all classes except on the quiz days. There were two quizzes (10% of the whole course) throughout the semester. Make sure you are present on those days.

For the tutorials, you MUST be present every time. It counts towards the tutorial performance (20% of the whole course). Remember to answer as many questions as you can, especially at the beginning of the course. As your tutor is rumored to be the one who marks your final essay, fighting for a better impression could bring you a little advantage.

The MOST IMPORTANT point: Before handing in the final essay, you are required to do your first draft and submit it to the tutor. DO IT SERIOUSLY so that you can ask for very valuable advice from your tutor. After you receive the feedback, you MUST correct your draft ACCORDING to the tutor's advice. That can guarantee a good mark for your final essay (50% of the whole course).Topic: Language, Communication, and Society.

Here are the areas of topic being discussed:
1. Pleasure, Happiness, and the 'Good Life'
2. The Meaning of Life
3. Self-Interest
4. Moral Conflict
5. Cultural Relativism
6. Utilitarianism
7. Are there absolute moral rules?
The topics explained through powerpoint presentations by the professors and individual assigned reading will then be used to write a term essay with the following titles:
1. Analyze the possible meanings of the ¡°good life.¡± State your own conception of the good life and why you think it is good.
2. Would you agree that all human actions are ultimately motivated by self-interest? Provide reasons for your agreement/disagreement.

3. On page 18 of The Elements of Moral Philosophy (Ch.2), James and Stuart Rachels provide the following argument against Cultural Relativism: ¡°In some societies, people believe the earth is flat. In other societies, such as our own, people believe that the earth is spherical. Does it follow, from the mere fact that people disagree, that there is no ¡®objective truth¡¯ in geography? ¡­Similarly, there is no reason to think that if there is moral truth everyone must know it. The Cultural Differences Argument tries to derive a substantive conclusion about a subject from the mere fact that people disagree. But this is impossible.¡± How conclusive is this argument against Cultural Relativism? In what sense may Cultural Relativism be valid?Professor Chong has a really soft and monotone voice. Not difficult but annoying.Content:
-Pleasure, happiness, the "Good Life"
-Meaning of life
-Self-interest
-Moral conflict
-Cultural relativism
-Utilitarianism
-Kantian ethics
Format:

Weekly lectures where the professor reads off the slides verbatim. Assigned weekly readings, but nobody really reads them until preparing for the quiz. Weekly tutorial "workshops" where the TA helps you prepare for the final essay (common sense tips about writing essays). Two quizzes on readings/lectures.
Assignments:
-Unlimited-retries online activities that should be an easy full score
-Online discussion about some topic discussed in class (i.e. post your thoughts and reply to others)
-Draft & final essay
Attendance:
-Random PRS polls the professor uses to record attendance during lectures

This course has 3 sections (L1, L2, L3) and each section has a completely different topic or theme, so what you learn in one section is completely different from the others. I suggest you check the topics of each section before selecting one, as they change every term/year I think.

Mine was L1: Happiness, self-interest and morality. Basically about different philosophical theories and ideas, sometimes a bit boring, but it was a more general theme, unlike other sections which focused on particular philosophies like ConfucianismTeaching during the lectures was boring... Of 400 people in the lecture about 300+ were sleeping or watching movies/chatting most of the time.

The instructor for the writing workshops was very good though. Very helpful and attentive, gives good, specific feedback at every step of the essay.Cultures and Values (L3): Morality and Emotions in Philosophy, Literature and Film

From the syllabus: (This course will explore the values of morality, love and beauty across diverse cultures in relationship to the individual¡¯s emotional well-being and chance to have a fulfilled life. We will address the following issues as reflected in a range of philosophical writings, literature, film and art: universal and culturally particular aspects of ethics and human nature; different conceptions of romantic love; as well as the appreciation of beauty and art.)You should expect the lectures to be boring and monotone. But the lecturer tries her best to make it fun and interactive.

As for the tutorials, I was fortunate enough to have Amy Chi. She is very nice, assertive at times. But she gets the job done. And, there are some PRS things.This course investigates the ideas and values of self, family, and society to better understand the mutual impact of society and culture on individuals, and of individuals on society and culture in the modern world. We will examine the above topics reflected in a variety of modern Western and Chinese philosophical, literary, cultural and filmic texts, from which to explore how the self and its relationship to family and society are conceptualized and defined in both Western and Chinese cultures. While examining how the concepts of self, family values, and social responsibilities are framed differently across the course of history in the West and China, this course also devotes attention to the interaction and appropriation of these concepts from the Western context into the Chinese context from comparative perspectives. Throughout, this introductory Humanities course aims to stimulate students to critically contemplate on their own conditions as modern individuals in the contemporary globalizing world.Teaching material is simple and easy to understanding with powerpoint & tutorial notes.its good to know. philosophical ideas. maybe helpful later when you have to consider about ethical issues.its good. but, there are so many people who are doing their own things. so hard to focus. its a huge class with 200 people.they give really good grades i think relative to endeavour that I put innot much things to do (essay. done. one quiz). Some period did go quite deep as it is long and famous. But some period Anna only use a few slides for introduction.Anna is a good instructor. She's very nice and open to all questions. She did ask questions in the lectures to allow us to think more and analysis more.

She is also multilingual but the problem is her voice is a bit low so it's quite easy to sleep in class. But she did upload the lecture videos online so you can always do review whenever you get lost in her lectures.Don't take the course if you're not very interested in western painting / or you have bad memory (there are people who get 30/30 for each quiz, you can't compete with them). You get insights to some famous, some less famous artists, and about 3-8 of their paintings.

She uses a lot of jargon so you should keep the glossary she hands out because at first, most words are latin and french etc.She goes into a lot of details. If you like art you'd find her interesting. If you don't, you'll probably end up falling asleep or focus on her groggy voice. She posts her lecture videos online so I really like that.

However, she made threatened us to go to the Monet art exhibition saying that there would be a question on it in the finals. There wasn't. (worth it but still.)Basically every important type of painting, with examples, that appeared in the West from ancient Greek vase painting to Andy Warhol.  Extremely comprehensive and informative if you really are into western painting.  Gives you a detailed overview of western art with some background history.  Anna also explained painting styles and techniques with a considerable amount of jargons (no, the majority of them are not English words).

I personally find the course not that challenging, but you'll need a good memory to score better than others in her quizzes.  Trust me, you'll always find someone who remembers everything and gets full scores, and some who choose not to remember a single word then get shitty scores.

The good news is, exams (or quizzes, the way she called them) are NOT accumulative.  In other words, 3000 years of western painting is divided (not equally) into 4 quizzes.Anna is a great lecturer.  Multilingual and extremely knowledgeable.  She explains things clearly and analyzes paintings not only from the aesthetics, but also from socio-economic conditions, history, religions and politics.

But the main problem, as JC mentioned in HUMA2680's review, is her unidirectional way of teaching.  You'll need to take tons of notes and be very focused to get the most out of her lectures (and yes, she'll include all those small things you thought you won't be tested on in her quizzes).1. Also you even have to attend some additional talk to get the credit!This course talks about the 4 periods in classical music which are Baroque, Classical, Romantic, and Twentieth Century periods. The professor will start with music from the Dark Ages first, and it's better if you understand that since he'll use this period for references in the future.

He'll talk about the composers, how an excerpt of a piece of classical music differs from or resonates with another, and how to spot the differences so we can know what piece is from which period. The professor will repeat those three anyways, so if you attend the lectures and really listen then you'll be able to get it.

No much interaction beside singingThe lectures cover almost the entire historical development of western music. The instructor begins with Middle Age music, followed by Medieval and Renaissance music. These musical eras only cover a small part of the syllabus. The main focus is on the common-practice period, which means the Baroque, Classical and Romantic periods. 20th Century music also possesses a significant part but the instructor may not go in depth.

The lecture slides introduce the history and culture of different musical periods and explain the characteristics of the compositions in the corresponding eras. A few examples of composers and their works will then be cited.
Some musical theories, such as circle of fifths are included as well. Students have to be familiar with the manipulation of musical keys such as parallel and relative major/minor and dominant keys.

The exams are likely to be precise and goes into details like the composers' nationality and the definition of musical terms.The lecture slides are very lucid, with a clear flow of ideas and explanations. However, there are still some questions on the slides that are answered neither on the slides or in the lectures. Another problem is the repetition of content. The instructor copies the slides that he has not covered onto the next slide. But overall the presentation is quite comprehensible.

The instructor emphasizes a lot on the concert report and he sometimes spend 1/3 of the lecture to talk about the details. However, the way he delivers the messages is outstanding. It will not be very hard for students without musical background to understand. His enthusiasm and attitude towards music is conspicuous.

Students must attend the Intimacy of Creativity Concerts as well as the discussion sessions but not everyone finds it interesting. Some of the students may not be able to appreciate the artistry and assimilate the communication between the musicians. Not much to say about his teaching because he just reads from the ppt and plays videos.The whole course consists
1.INTRODUCTION/MEDIEVAL MUSIC
A discussion of Medieval culture, sacred music (including the Medieval mass and motet), and secular forms will cover the work of composers Hildegard of Bingen, Leonin, Perotin, and Machaut.
Music theory concepts related to these works will include fundamentals of rhythm, meter, and melody.
2. RENAISSANCE MUSIC

A discussion of Renaissance culture, vocal music (including the Renaissance mass and motet, and madrigal), and instrumental music will include works by composers Josquin Des Prez and Giovanni Pierluigi da Palestrina.
Music theory concepts will continue with a brief discussion of elementary contrapuntal techniques.
3. BAROQUE MUSIC

An in-depth analysis of the musical genres from the Baroque period will cover the work of composers Bach, Handel, Purcell, Pachelbel, Corelli, and others.  The section will begin with a discussion of the art, culture, and general philosophy of music during this time period followed by a discussion of vocal genres (oratorio, cantata, and opera) and instrumental genres (the suite, and sonata).

Related music theory concepts will include an introduction to key signatures, major and minor scales, and the circle of fifths.  This will also include a short discussion of the elements of the fugue, and compositional devices like the sequence.
4. CLASSICAL PERIOD MUSIC
This section will cover the works of Haydn, Mozart, and Beethoven, focusing on the
development of vocal genres (including opera) and instrumental genres (including the sonata).
In addition, new genres of the concerto and symphony will be covered.
5. ROMANTIC MUSIC
The most extensive section of the semester will begin with a discussion of the chamber music
of early eighteenth century composers Schubert, Mendelssohn, Chopin, and Liszt.
The section will continue with an overview of the continuing development of opera, including
the work of Verdi, Puccini, and Wagner and cover new genres of ballet and program music
with the works of composers Berlioz, Strauss, and Tchaikovsky.
Music from the second half of the eighteenth century will include works by late Romantic
composers Brahms and Tchaikovsky, and nationalist works by Tchaikovsky, Mussorgsky,
Smetana, and others.
The development of harmony and form during this period will be covered as it relates to the
works discussed.
6. TWENTIETH CENTURY ART MUSIC

Lectures will cover the many styles of art music during the twentieth century, beginning with works by early twentieth century composers Debussy, Ravel, Rachmaninoff, Stravinsky, Bartok, Schoenberg, and others.  Impressionism, neo-Romanticism, expressionism, and primitivism will be examined along with neoclassicism and 12-tone music.
The section will continue with works by composers of second half of the twentieth century,
including Var¨¨se, Crumb, Cage, Copland, and others.
A short discussion of the radical development of theoretical concepts will focus on rhythm
(including ostinato complex, polyrhythm), harmony (including polytonality), and serialism as

Biweekly lectures where the professor discusses the assigned readings from the previous class (one to two stories).
Assignments:
-Weekly readings (the short stories are mostly under a few pages)
-One group presentation about some common theme in a few stories
-One short essay about some common theme in a selection of stories of your choice (800 word limit)

Since the course content jumps from one country to another in mere weeks, and many of the historical events happened in intertwining manners, one may find writing up timelines useful.Professor Joshua Derman is a very nice professor who knows his course materials well. HELP:Amazing professor. Knows  his material. Interactive classroom. The course is divided into three parts: Hitler's Nazi Germany, Mussolini's Fascist Italy, and Stalin's Soviet Union. The time period spans from the eve of WWI to the defeat of Axis in the WWII.

Each lecture contains about 20 to 30 pages of PPT that would be tested on the exam.The teaching is beyond perfection. In fact, this is the best course I have ever taken at HKUST. So it can be hard to catch up if you fail to organize the information.Course provides a systematic introduction on the structure of human language in a linguistic point of view.
Covers topics:
Structures of sentences / words (morphemes)
4 principles of human language,
Difference between human language and other animals
Difference between genders on language (psychological view)
Social factors affecting language
How children master their mother tongue
Different Accents and usage of a certain language
**PHONETICS is a HUGE part of the course.**
- Phonetic symbols in English, requires reciting. Usage:  pronunciation, stressing, aspiration

- Other languages covered: Cantonese (emphisizing on tones), Mandarin, Thai, Hindi, Japanese, Korean (some of which is required in the FINAL exam)Prof NG is one of the more interesting professors in HKUST. He tries to make his classes less dull, often pulling puns and jokes on himself and students (no offense) and frequently interacts with his students. He remembers every single student by name. Class ambience is usually laid back and fun.
He gives out a large amount of handouts (THOUGH REALLY UNORGANIZED) which you are required to keep because they are essential for exam revisions.

Videos and slideshows are frequently used in classes and you are required to remember minor details and quotes within these materials as they are assessed in exams (which is quite ridiculous if you ask me as it depends how well you generally remember things).

The biggest problem is the inconsistency of content within classes. (for summer, 3.5hr courses, breaks included) He tends to skip around covering fundamental topics and phonetics which makes it really difficult to organize your notes well (provided you will jot notes in the first place).

Course also covers foreign languages e.g. Hindi, Thai, Japanese, Mandarin which is somewhat difficult to master within a short period of time if you're not a "language" person, but they will be assessed in the exam.The content discussed in the course includes general classifications of different fields in linguistics (not important), phonetics&acoustics (v. important), animal communication, some neurolinguistics, some sociolinguistics, etc. before the midterm, final largely focuses on differences between male and female and study of chinese, japanese and korean.
In general not hard, especially if you know phonetics of English already, not much to memorize (phonetics, hiragana, some classification of words, etc.), other things tested in exam is common sense

Exam not too difficult, make sure you have revised all handouts distributed during class and memorize stuffs on the review list should be enough for an A range already.The instructor is quite enthusiastic and dynamic, however, he always jump from one topic to another topic suddenly, may be hard to follow at first.

This course focus on the text written by famous philosophical thinkers in different era and different region, including Mengzi, Arendt, Socrates e.t.c. Refer to the attached document for topics included.

Overall I would consider the content as interesting as it raise questions on the justification of some concepts which we assume to be true, for example why can we assure the knowledge we know must be true? However do note that some concepts involved might be quite abstract and difficult to understand. Also ensure your English proficiency required is quite high for academic reading of philosophical papers or you will suffer from inability to understand the reading materials.I would describe him as a mediocre professor. His speaks with monotone so people may fall asleep easily in his lecture. However content wise he did make his best attempt to translate the abstract concepts to real-life examples and explain the contents in detail. Overall I would say his strength is in content while his weakness is in his teaching style.

On the other hand, the TA (LAW, Chun Yin) out-stands from most other TA I have met. He gives great details to some difficult concepts in the canvas discussion. He is also very patient in answering students questions, so if you have any confusion about the contents, please feel free to ask him.

P. S. 1. Indeed the professor tried to make the lecture more interactive by raising some questions and expecting students volunteer to answer. However in my point of view, the nature of Hong Kong educational system makes Hong Kong people feel shy to answer questions in class, so only very few responded to his questions.

However, since the questions in the exams are very straight-forward and doesn't required critical thinking, it means that you would be able to get the answers right if you have study, read through the powerpoint thoroughly, and really memorize all the materials in the ppt then you would be good to go. Bad news.This course basically is try to lead year 1 QSA student to be familiar with and prepare for their study in HKUST.Every week with have some new topics to talk about, for example: exchange, school policy, internship, QSA major requirement discussion etc... I think the content with be different in every year. But overall is quite good, and i think it worth your time to attend this course.The course is basically divided into 2 parts (arguably 2 and a half), separated by the midterm exam. A brief history of East Asia after WWII is outlined before the midterm, topics discussed include cold war (which will be a recurring theme in the course afterwards), korean war, vietnamese war, bandung conference, sino-india conflicts, sino-soviet split, sino-US relationships, reformation by gorbachev, etc. Midterm exam consists of MCQs only yet they are not easy, understandings on small details (eg. chronological orders of events in a certain war), readings (including comparisons between the arguments proposed by different scholars, meaning that thorough understanding and memory on readings are required, including the names of the author, FML), and something only mentioned in class but not on the slides are required. After the midterm exam, the focus of the course turns into explanation of historical events, different IR theories are introduced, explaining why a certain state would make certain decisions. The 0.5 part is the simulation game which the professor has put a lot of focus in, students are divided into groups, representing different countries and organisations and thrown in to a situation that a conflict may happen

Final exam requires you to answer 4 out of 6 essay type questions in 2 hours, yet ~20 possible questions are given in advance so you can prepare a brief outline beforehand.The professor is enthusiastic and teaches with much passion, slides are used as outline only and details are either skipped or barely mentioned, he likes to ask questions and be asked during lectures, and would lightly mock you if you refuse to answer his questions. Logical flow is a bit lacking and the amount of information conveyed is quite large, but following shd not be too hard if do pay attention during lectures.Interesting contents, history buffs and social science lovers will love this course more than any other courses in HKUST.

Despite its name, it does not only focus on 'the International Relations of East Asia' but also tend to focus on the United States and South East Asian countries such as the three indochina nations and Taiwan (it might count as East Asia but...)  Well, does not hurt you, it is true that knowledge on these nations is crucial to understand the East Asian history and politics.The lectures are very interesting; partly because I am originally fond of social science, and mostly because professor knows how to tell interesting social science jokes which I enjoyed a LOT.

Course Description: This course introduces the fundamental theories of microeconomics and macroeconomics. Topics include consumer theory, producer theory, the behavior of firms, market equilibrium, monopoly, the role of the government in the economy, long-run economic growth, the monetary system, and the open-economy macroeconomics.
Intended Learning Outcomes:
On completion of the course, students are expected to be able to:
? Understand the basic logic of economic reasoning;
? Apply basic economic analysis to explain and predict economic relationships;
? Have a deeper understanding of economic issues and events;
? Make critical evaluations on views and opinions related to economics.
Readings:
? The required textbook is Principles of Economics, 6e (2012) by N. Gregory Mankiw,
which is available at the bookstore and also reserved in the library. You are also encouraged to browse the author¡¯s blog () and read economic and social news.
Grading: 15% Two pop-up quizzes 35% Midterm exam (June 28)
50% Comprehensive final exam
Course Outline:
Note: This is a preliminary list of topics; I may add topics, remove topics or switch the order of topics depending on how the class is progressing.
I. Introduction: basic principles of economics
II. The market system of demand and supply
III. How price regulations and tax policies affect the outcomes of the market
IV. Basic welfare analysis of tax policy
V. The problem areas for the market and government policies to deal with market failure VI. Competition, monopoly, and the organization of industry
VII. The market for labor
IX. Basic concepts in macroeconomics
VIII. Economic growth
X. The monetary system

XI. Basic concepts of open-economy macroeconomics (if time permits)normalThe first three chapters are about microeconomics, and the other eleven chapters are about macroeconomics. The content is abundant and useful, especially for students from science and engineering. The tutorials are optional, mainly recapping the lecture materials.The course goes over the economic development and societal changes of China over the last 1000 years or so, with more focus on recent centuries. The changes are analysed under different social theories and analysis methods.

This course should provide you with fundamental knowledge about the interaction of science and technology in our life which will help you become more mindful of the mutual influence of science and technology on society.The professor assessed our understandings by asking us to apply the factual and conceptual knowledge we had learnt to case study analysis. This was done through case studies included in mid-term and final exams and through the assessment of case study reports from group discussion in class.
During lectures, he would illustrate the mutual influence of technology and society with case studies and/or videos, and discuss those with students in class.

There is no attendance requirement, but the in-class PRS is kind of an indicator.Here is the objectives in the syllabus:

"The course aims to provide students with theoretical and conceptual tools to understand the way scientific and technological decisions are made, and the effects that these decisions in turn have on social development. It will encourage students to analyse technology from different perspectives, to ask informed questions about the driving forces of science and technology, and to form their own opinions about the role of science and technology in our contemporary society."
In this course, I mostly learned about history in the first half semester, and some easy theoritical stuffs in the second half semester.

Pretty interesting, and what you will learn is usually in line with common sense.He is quite good, and very nice. He always plays his favorite songs in the beginning of the lessons. Overall, he was a very kind person.Mainly talks about the history of technological development from the Stone Age all the way up to the Industrial Revolution and now. Covers concepts such as technological momentum, social lag and the socio-technological system, which are very straight-forward and assessed many many MANY times in the final. In other words, as long as you understand a concept, you can get many questions correct in a row as they are basically asking about the same thing. The midterm and final both consist of multiple choice questions only, usually providing a scenario and asking you the name of the relevant concept. The most tricky part is that you have to recite the complete history of technology covered in the course down to the very last detail, as even the name of a prehistorical species mentioned in the first ppt slide of the first lecture may be assessed in the final. You also have to read the whole textbook provided on the course website, as some questions will be asked.Prof. Baark is a nice person, he sometimes jokes about himself during lessons and he even gave us cookies made by his wife. He always asks us to raise question during the lecture, and remind us to do the readings on the reading list he given.At the beginning (before the midterm) it went through some basic economic concepts which has been taught in high school.
The midterm covers:
1. Law of Demand
2. Demand and Supply
3. Equilibrium and efficiency
4. Externality
5. Coasm Theorem
6. Public goods

If you are a local student and studied ECON in DSE, those should be easy. But be careful about the efficiency part in midterm, because the question the prof asked about externality and efficiency is quite complicated for me.
After the midterm, the topics taught are new to me.
The final covers:
1. Valuing the environment
(This part is about how to measure the value of a good which does not have a market price. i.e. Hedonic approach, travel cost modelling and avoidance costs)
2. VSL (Value of a Statistical Life)
(Trying to estimate a single human life in the society and discussion on the ethical issue)
3. Benefit-Cost Analysis
(A method to determine whether we should implement a policy or not, a process to go through in policy making)
4. Environmental and Health
(Link environmental risk to human health and quantify the effect with the above methods)
5. Markets with asymmetric information
(the lemon effect, moral hazard and averse selection)
6. Climate change and its effect in China
7. Second Best Theoryquite good i think

There will be little gossips about contemporary political situations, but there will be a lot of concepts about political philosophy and political structure.James Wong is a passionate lecturer. 3 hours lecture should be boring but his teaching style is quite interesting.This course introduces students to two main fields of political studies ¨C political theory and comparative politics. Political theory looks at the normative world of politics, seeking to evaluate and recommend political arrangements through the study of concepts and ideologies. Comparative politics looks at the empirical world of politics, seeking to understand and explain political phenomena through the study of actors, institutions, and their dynamics. Students benefit from the analytical knowledge and skills as well as the political sense and awareness for surviving in a ¡®politicized¡¯ world.
1. Introduction / Politics and the state
2. Political power, authority, and the state
3. Democracy and political obligation
4. Freedom and justice
5. Traditional ideologies
6. Contemporary ideologies
7. Laws, constitutions, and federalism
8. Votes, elections, legislatures, and legislators
9. Political parties
10. Executives, bureaucracies, policy studies, and governance
11. Civil society, interest groups, and the media

12. Democracies, democratization, and authoritarian regimesThe lecturer is REALLY FUN. He has a great sense of humor, extremely local-friendly - he would joke about current political news. His English is nice and fluent, a bit British accent as he got his phd from London School of Economics. He gives two breaks in a 3 hour lecture, which is very considerate. Very clear powerpoint slides, you can basically skip all lectures if you read through all the slides and with the supplement of the textbook. Grade: A-If you are a participant in social movements, I suggest you having this course. The course introduces terms that are somewhat commonly talked in political news, but people rarely understand this well. For example, the ideology of different government, and how parties differ the state. Most importantly, the course introduces the basic concept of a state, and how it is different with a country. Based on this, Hong Kong can be consider as a state, but not a country. This perspective are quite useful inJames Wong taught quite well. He could implement the concept with the international and local news. For example, the Britexit movement was on the headlines at that time. He could really know where students will get lost in. One thing that is great is that he had printed notes each lecture. (Of cause you can download in Canvas too)Pretty informative and interesting. He is quite funny and explained everything in detail. But his English speaking may not be accurate enough sometimes.There are three exams in total, all exam questions are essay format.
First exam (60 points), Second Exam (60 points), Final Exam (80 points) with a total of 200 points.

Also, there are a total of 5 extra quizzes, in which you can earn 2 extra points at maximum in each quiz. It is very easy to get full mark. The quiz is held before the end of particular lesson and Professor will tell in the class in advance.
The course is absolute grading as told by professor in the class. But I think it is not actually because I got only like 87% even though I counted the 10 points from extra quiz. I got A.
First exam: 51/60  Mean: 51.7
Midterm: 52/60  Mean: 52.9
Final exam: 70/80  Mean: 67.4
The lowest scored person still have 7x%, which implies it is very difficult to get C range.Three exams are distributed throughout the semester. The good thing is it is non-cumulative.

It is important to attend every lessons so as to jot note. There are so extra information and examples that can help you better understand it as well as preparing the exam. Those examples are quite useful.The lecture can be divided into three parts.

Part I studies theories of modernization and dependency and new dependent development theory. These concepts help explain why there are differences in development for the third world countries and developed countries. You can treat this part as a foundation.
Part II studies the world-systems perspective and this is useful for explaining development project (1945-1970s) and the globalization project (the 1980s -the present).

Part III is about the historical study of East Asia over the past two centuries.  It covered the issues related to socialist revolution and post-socialist transformation in China, the rise of Japan, national reunification project etc.Professor So explains the concept very clearly and he is willing to answer your questions. The content itself is quite easy to understand.Prof. Cho's teaching is decent. She prepares powerpoints for students, but there are fill in the blanks, meaning you would have to attend the classes. Psychoanalytic, trait, behavioural, cognitive, biological and humanistic approaches are covered, she has a final wrap up for the integration (though it was a really quick and short one)Michelle is a funny instructor, although she set guidelines in the first class and then 1/3 of the class dropped out (perhaps people are scared by her). She included many experience in the class so the pace of teaching is quite slow. Michelle is one of the best professors I have had in UST. There were active class discussions. She asked us to submit a query sheet after every chapter. This helped us understand each topic better. Even though the class is three hours, one would not feel bored. If you're an international student, be prepared for Michelle to ask you many questions during the lecture.It cover almost all social science discipline
Including psychology, economy, political science, public policy, demography and other disciplines.

It will be a interesting course if you like social science, and can provide you a brief and wide understanding of each social science discipline.As Cameron is the coordinator of this course, he will appear in this course every time, but all he does is just take attendance.
