Every lesson will be featured with different guest lecturer, mostly from HKUST, but some of them are from other university as well, and they will talk about different social science discipline by talking about their research or briefly talk about the course content that they are teaching.
Although there are some boring lecturer, most of them are interesting and able to bring some new insights to me.
Also, because all of them use english as teaching medium, if you are not good at english you will find it quite difficult to follow (eg me)It covers everything.

The course can be divided into 2 parts. The first is the videos. You are required to watch them online. In the video, you can see how Cameron do the presentation... I'm just kidding. The video mainly focuses on introducing basic knowledge of social science research.

The second part is the lecture. Different instructors with different research interests are invited to the class. Case analysis is the most interesting part of the lecture.Cameron is nice and patient. He served as a guide in this semester for QSA students.

As for other instructors, once you concentrate on their research, you will never find this course boring.Different professors will come and share, which is quite fun in my view. All professors talk about social science topics like sociology or psychology and stuffs like that.Cameron don't teach much directly since it is basically sharing of many guests but the flow of the class is alright.

It is fun that professor gave us links of his online courses and told us to watch them, yet it is pretty much unrelated with the exam or whatsoever, and that most of the students just dont watch them at all. No computer/ mobile device could be used in the lecture, may be quite harsh to some students.Before midterm: More about sociological concepts like correspondence principle, labeling theory, hidden curriculum

After midterm: Applying sociological concepts into current education system, ranging from HK higher education system to the Finnish system. To be exact, I would just quote some guided questions in the syllabus that I received at the first class.

The course will initiate a sociologically informed conversation about education.What is school for?What social forces have shaped our current educational practices? Does schooling provide new opportunities, or perpetuate old inequalities? How are ethnic minorities marginalized from education systems? Why do boys perform so poorly compared to girls in our schools? What should be the role of the humanities and creativity in education? Why is there a ¡°crisis¡± in higher education?How might education be reformed?To answer these questions, we will study a number of important sociological works on education and you will be encouraged to reflect upon your own educational experiences, as well as examine contemporary debates about education at all levels in Hong Kong, and across cultures.His teaching is quite good and he is very willing to help any students who cannot follow. Course Description

The aim of this course is to introduce the research methods and the fundamental concepts and theories in various areas in psychology. This course is suitable for students who want to acquire a basic understanding of psychology, and prerequisite for students who want to take further courses in psychology.
1. Introduction Ch. 1
2. Research Methods Ch. 2
3. Memory Ch. 7
4. Learning Ch. 6
5. Sensation and Perception Ch. 4
6. States of Consciousness Ch. 5
7. Quiz 1
8. Intelligence Ch. 9
9. Development Ch. 12
10. Personality Ch. 13
11. Health Psychology Ch. 14
12. Social Psychology Ch. 17

The course talks about the poverty situation all over the world (it does not focus only in a certain region) so I find it quite interesting.

- how to analyse poverty with different statistical methods.
- WHY are some countries wealthier and poorer than others in multiple aspects

Although I am just a year 1, the content is not difficult at all.  Just some basic graphs, analyzing the trends of the poverty situation of some countries and some measures to fight poverty.  You are required to remember some facts about the poverty situation.  However mid term and final will not ask those facts in a very detailed way.  Maybe 1 or 2 MC questions asking those facts.  No worry if you did not study that part!!!!!!Professor Wang tried to create a more interesting teaching atmosphere.  She requires us to have some kind of discussions with our group members during class.  However, due to the content of this course, it is very difficult to have an interesting learning atmosphere. This course aims to make students gain familiarity with poverty issues including poverty measurement, underlying causes of poverty, the impact of poverty on society and government programs and policies that address poverty. We will illustrate principles with real-world applications. Though the course discusses poverty in a broad context of developing and developed countries, an extra emphasis will be put on poverty related issues in Hong Kong and mainland China.Just read out the content on the slides

Boring and often starts late and ends earlyThe first half of the course is about the concept of poverty; how to measure poverty; gender, ethnic and age inequality. The later half is about the cause of poverty from the perspective of geography, culture and institutions and the focus is how to fight poverty.

Easy to understand and can raise your interest if you haven't taken any sosc course.The professor has been teaching the course continually for several semesters, so the teaching is quite skillfully. The course has four major components:
1 Midterm 30%
2 Final 35%
3 PRS 15% (Best 15 out of 17/ while the 17 are selected from a pool of 20 by the professor)
4 Group Discussion 20% (Best 4 out of 5)

I got a B+ eventually
Midterm: mean
Final: +0.6 SD
PRS: Full mark
Discussion: Mostly above mean (8.5-9/10)You have to go class even though he won't take attendance.

The professor will take PRS at any time. (Mostly at the beginning of each lesson). You will score 10 points for the correct answer but 4 points for the incorrect answer. (So answering wrongly is still better than answering nothing)
There will be 5 group works throughout the semester, which is to write a short essay for 1-2 pages. It has to be done during the lesson so you don't have any group work to do at home.

Other than that, the workload is not heavy at all since I didn't do any readings. Memorizing all the powerpoint slides the night before exam is enough to attain at least B range.The course serves as a good introduction to the relationship between science, technology and the workplace, and the growth of economies from the era of the industrial revolution to today. The lecture slides are concise and contain all the relevant information in an easy to read format. Most of the readings are also very interesting, albeit rather long. At the end of the course the professor provided reading summaries so that wasn't too much of a problem.I was never really interested in the social sciences, but the professor managed to keep me engrossed in all of his lectures. His analysis and lectures are in depth but easy to understand. He encourages questions in class and answers them all very well. He also makes sure he entertains all the student feedback that he can.Content is interesting, it gives a lot of insight to the history of the merging of science, technology and work. The lecture includes a lot of videos as well, though it is not included in the mid-term and final exams. The contentThe professor is great. clear explanations, well thought out answers in response to students questions, interesting teaching and his tone won't make you fall asleepContent is slightly lengthy, although you get to learn quite a lot about how society has changed through the past few centuries in terms of science technology and work environment. You get to learn some interesting features about how different parts of the world go through similar changes but at different time periods.Teach is great, even though the content did not interest me, the way he teaches pulls you into it. You won't get bored in this class as the topics are interesting and applicable to our daily lives. I was taking Management at that time and I found that I was able to relate certain concepts to it as well. You will learn about the different scientific practices and technologies that affects how we work. Topics include bureaucracy, scientific management, taylorism, fordism, mcdonaldization of society etc.Prof teaches really well. He doesn't take attendance, and says in his very first class that he doesn't mind if you don't attend his lectures. But it is definitely worth it to go for his lectures as he shows videos and gives extra information. You won't fall asleep in class as he's able to deliver the content really well and provide interesting tidbits during lectures.This course start with introducing what is science and technology. Coming with scientific management, taylorism, fordism, deskilling, reskilling and bureaucracy... This course looks into how science and technology change our workplace through time.
There is irregular prs quiz, 5 in-class assignment done in group, midterm exam (25 mcs and 2 short questions), final exam (25 mcs and few short questions; not accumulative).

PRS may pop up sharp at the starting time of class. Most mcs in this course is examining how well you have memorized the course materials so they are quite easy. Only few of them are a bit tricky. The short questions in exams are quite straight forward too.

The in-class group assignment is responding to one question with the reading materials and notes in a one page length answer. It might be a bit challenging in the first/ second time because of the time limit.Professor is very passionate. He explain key ideas very well through his deep analyze but somehow it may take up to half of the class time.

He is also very open minded. He welcome all kinds of comments or questions both in class and after class. He is very willing to adjust his teaching by asking us what he can improve, like the pace he speak, readings are needed or not. He also send us practice questions to prepare the midterm exam.

He also maintain a good atmosphere in the class by playing different music from youtube before class and in between break.You'd find that there re still serious gender discrimination and inequality everywhere even in the modern society today.I learn interesting facts and cases on the topic. I like the whole structure of the class, it encourages questioning and creative ideas.Interactive teaching style, nice English, guest lectures and video watching all the timeNo CommentThe instructor was very interactive with students. Lectures are well prepared with lots of real life examples and in-class activities. There are not a lot of content in powerpoints or notes. So although there is no attendance requirement, you have to attend the lectures as the contents and examples from impromptu in-class discussions will be tested.topic1: biology, sex and gender
topic2: inequality in everyday life
topic3: men and women in the workplace and at home
topic4: men and women in intimate relationships
topic5: men and women in the global economy

The purpose of this courses is to let us develop a sociological mindfulness about the importance of gender in society. We will view gender as the product of culture, groups, and organizations. We are also required to pay attention to behaviors and ways of thinking that are so taken-for-granted that we fail to question them.The professor always encourages class discussion and is willing to answer students' questions, both in class and outside of class. He usually uses powerpoint to present his points and plays videos to illustrate opinions on the topic from different stakeholders. However, he is very strict on the use of mobile phones and laptop computers.The content was easy to be understood. It is about some common issues topics on Gender, such as gender violence, gender in the working environment, dating, and other interesting topics about gender.Basically, you have to read all of the readings before you attend each lesson. The lesson will be conducted based on the readings every week. There will be some discussions concerning on the gender topics within the classroom during lessons, and the powerpoint basically only pictures and examples, so you just need to read every reading to understand the topics.The course is divided into 5 parts
1. Biological sex and gender
2. Inequality in everyday life
3. Men and women in the workplace and the home
4. Men and women in intimate relationships
5. Men and women in the global economy
Content are quite interesting as they all related to our daily life

However, when it comes to the real deal, that is not the case. I can learn little things from this course as there is not having any in-depth discussions in class. Though classes were funny sometimes, but the professors are clearly giving spending too much time letting us to express our views, and that is the main problem of the whole course.

If you were taking this course at the time like I do, you would absolutely be frustrated how "messy" this course is. You would expect 20-30% of the lecture time listening to different students raising up hands, talking some very common, basic things, that I think will not lead us to a more fruitful and productive discussion.No phone and notebook in class
Professor tried to show much short videos and documentaries to make the classes more interesting
Sometimes professor talked in a very soft and slow manner, making lectures a bit boring

IF YOU ARE AN INTROVERTED OR TRADITIONAL HONG KONG STUDENT WHO DON'T REALLY SPEAK AT ALL. I STRONGLY ADVISE YOU TO THINK TWICE BEFORE YOU TAKE THIS COURSE. THAT 10% EXTRA CREDITS IS REALLY A BIG DEAL TO YOUR FINAL GRADE. IF YOU SPEND ALL THE TIME IN THE LECTURE SITTING STILL AND DO NOTHING SPEAKING, DEFINITELY YOU ARE GOING TO BE FXXXED IN YOUR GRADING, BECAUSE THERE ARE GOING TO BE AROUND 10% STUDENTS GETS MORE THAN 3% OF EXTRA CREDITS IN THIS COURSES DUE TO THEIR FREQUENT CONTRIBUTION.During lectures, he usually brings up a discussion question for the class to talk about. To make the class more interesting, he also show us short video clips about gender. Most of his power point notes are from the required or supplementary readings he gave us.He knows how to keep the class active by asking questions and showing us interesting video clips.Various interesting topics regarding to gender, for example, women rights and glass ceiling, were covered in class, on notes as well as in assigned readings. Things I learnt in class can also used in daily life discussion on other matters within sociological aspects.Prof. Groves often tried to make the class lively by adding videos, interesting discussions and even inviting people to give talks.The content covered gender in the workplace, gender in violence, issues such as homosexuality, and the development of gendered traits (males are supposed to be competitive, while females are supposed to be caring). This course really opens up everyone's mind and I recommend students to take this course.Brilliant. Dr. Groves is one of the best professors in UST. A lot of discussions take place in the classes. He actively engages students into contributing ideas in the class. He invites guest speakers to talk about the gender issues in the workplaces of Hong Kong.The purpose of this course is to answer these questions and others by developing a sociological mindfulness about how gender operates in our society. By sociologically mindful, I mean that we will view gender as the product of culture, groups, and organizations. I also mean that we will be paying attention to behaviours and ways of thinking that are so taken-for-granted that we often fail to question them, with an eye to examining the nature of inequality between men and women.  The course will be organized around five main topics: 1. Gender and Biology 2. Gender and Everyday Life  3. Gender at Work and in the Home  4. Gender and Intimate Relationships and 5. Gender in the Global Economy.  The focus of our discussions will be on gender issues in Hong Kong.He is really a good teacher. He initiates many discussion during the lesson in order to help us to understand more on the required readings. He also invites organisations outside to give us talk in order to provide us more information in the reality.The content is well designed and there are plenty of interesting things you can learn and be amazed. During and after the course, you may be able to understand why some of the gender issues are happening in this world in a more thorough and concrete manner. The content covers issue just as women in workplace, lesbian/gay, sexist language, and many more.Prof. Groves is amazing teacher. He presents idea very well in a very concise and sometimes funny manner. He likes to engage students in the class and listen to different opinions. I would definitely want to take many other courses he teaches next year2740 offers good insight into Gender Sociology, but it might feel one sided/too narrowly focused if you don't have a burning passion for Gender Studies/introductory Sociology knowledge. Having said that, it definitely changed the way I view the world. If you're just looking to fulfill an SA, I'd recommend 1850 with the same prof: varied, interesting, rich intro to Sociology. Groves is a brilliant lecturer.Brilliant lecturer. Engaging, interesting, has almost a stage presence. Best lecturer I've yet had. Groves implements case study + example-based learning approach, with supplementary videos and guest speakers. When I took it I think we had four guest speakers peppered throughout the term.
